Issues.Title: [Accessiblity] Narrator cannot announced the items correctly when switching the items by using up/down keyboard arrow that without expand the dropdown list panel
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

.NET SDK 10.0.100-alpha.1.24553.3

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

No

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

No, this issue cannot repro in .NET 3.1, can repro in .NET 5.0.

.NET 3.1:
![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/3cd87bea-659a-445b-b475-8468be30fe5b)


### Issue description

When switching the items by using up/down keyboard arrow that without expand the dropdown list panel, Narrator announced the FlatStyle/BoserStyle property item twice, the first time unread in its entirety.
![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/2c860186-92be-4cac-a191-6959995cedbd)

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/d30d1426-f17c-4922-81fc-3cd33c0f14f9

**Expected behavior:**
Compare with NVDA tool, Narrator should be read the FlatStyle/BoserStyle property item only once and in its entirety.
![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/3f29b2b9-88c0-4a73-9268-48dde318729e)

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/6627cef4-ac48-4c10-a48b-8d1b938d0d2b



### Steps to reproduce

1. Create a .NET Core Winforms project.
2. Add a Label and PropertyGrid controls in form designer. 
3. Set the SelectedObject property to Label1 in propertyGrid1 control. 
4. Build and run project.
5. Open Narrator tool and select FlatStyle/BoserStyle property in propertyGrid control.
6. Use keyboard up and down key to select property item.

**More info:**
1. The issue cannot reproduce on standard combobox control.
2. The issue also can reproduce with other properties.
3. This issue cannot repro in NVDA tool.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[Accessiblity] Narrator cannot announced the items correctly when switching the items by using up/down keyboard arrow that without expand the dropdown list panel" (#12421)

Issues.Title: Adding the project name to the class of a user control in the toolbox.
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

.net 8

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

Yes

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

_No response_

### Issue description

I just noticed that when creating a user control, the project name was added in parentheses after the name of the user control class in the toolbox.
The project name is already used as the name of the tab.
This display mode is identical after installing a nuget package including user controls.
Can't we remove this project name that is not on the other items in the toolbox?
In previous versions of visual studio, the project name was not visible.

After installing the nuget package containing the user controls in a new solution, I was able to rename the elements in the toolbox using a right click on the element and the context menu.
Unfortunately after reloading the solution, the old names reappear in the toolbox.

My current version of visual studio is 17.11.5 with .net 8.
I work in VB.net.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/f5f0e62e-9d8e-461a-a078-1c63c3639b42)

### Steps to reproduce

Create a solution with a user control and a windows form project.
The windows form project must have a dependency with the user control.
Open the windows form project form in design mode.
Check the toolbox
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Adding the project name to the class of a user control in the toolbox." (#12404)

Issues.Title: Mark Test Utilities As Packable Nonshipping
Issues.Body:
Mark some of our test utilities in a project that is packable nonshipping in preparation to share this with WPF. In this PR I've:
- Moved winforms specific test utilities out to the respective test utility assembly they were being used in which for the most part was System.Windows.Forms.TestUtilities
- Renamed System.Windows.Forms.Common.TestUtilities to System.Private.Windows.Core.TestUtilities to match our already shared assembly System.Private.Windows.Core
- Added/updated documentation for remaining classes/methods in System.Private.Windows.Core.TestUtilities

Next step here is to investigate if it is possible to have documentation for classes/methods in our shared assembly show up in intellisense within WPF repo but keep it out of windowsdesktop. Currently developers need to navigate via F12 to see any documentation for System.Private.Windows.Core.
 ###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](https://microsoft.github.io/open-pr/?codeflow=https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/12407)

Issues.Body:
### .NET version

NET SDK 10.0.100-alpha.1.24527.7

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

No, the issue can reproduce on Desert mode on windows11 & White mode on windows 10, cannot reproduce with other high contrast modes
![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/4b842f73-9af3-46ec-9082-2f1f137512bc)

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

No, the issue can reproduce all previous .NET SDK versions.

### Issue description

Cannot spot the small square on PrintPreviewControl the for the Accessibility Insight tools on all HC themes
![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/dd4806e7-c29b-40bc-bcdd-1f6f5d2949ed)



### Steps to reproduce

1. Create a .NET WinForms project 
2. Add printPreviewControl from toolBox to form designer or call printPreviewDialog to showDialog
3. Add the App.minifest file for the project and uncommand below code line 
```
<!-- Windows 10 --> 
      <supportedOS Id="{8e0f7a12-bfb3-4fe8-b9a5-48fd50a15a9a}" /> 
```
4. Set the contrast themes 
5. Build and run the project 
6. Open the Accessibility Insight tool, and using the color contrast function 
7. Spot the small square on the current focus area 

**Actually Results:** 
Cannot spot the small square on PrintPreviewControl the for the Accessibility Insight tools on all HC themes

**Expected Results:** 
Can spot the small square on PrintPreviewControl the for the Accessibility Insight tools on all HC themes


**More info:**
1.  The issue can reproduce on both windows11 and wndows10.
2. The issue can reproduce from .NET SDK 3.1 to 10.0.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Accessibility] Cannot spot the small square on PrintPreviewControl the for the Accessibility Insight tools on all HC themes" (#12401)

Issues.Title: The toolbox does not display the bitmap of the tool control installed by a nuget package.
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

.Net 8

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

No

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

_No response_

### Issue description

The value of the ToolboxBitmap attribute is not taken into account after installing a nuget package of controls in the toolbox.
This is a problem reported in different forums for a long time without ever finding a solution.
There was no problem when you could choose the dll of the custom control to incorporate into the toolbox.

My current version of visual studio is 17.11.5 with .net 8.
I work in VB.net.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/a616fc94-f7cc-49a9-b94c-8d8ec502cee3)


### Steps to reproduce

Create a user control with an image in the resources and add the ToolboxBitmap attribute as shown in the image.
Create the nuget package with user control.
Install this nuget package in a new solution.
Check the toolbox.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "The toolbox does not display the bitmap of the tool control installed by a nuget package." (#12403)
